'''[[Galadriel]]'s messages''' were messages given by Galadriel to [[Gandalf]] the White during his stay in [[Lothlórien]] after his [[Battle of the Peak|battle]] with the [[Durin's Bane|Balrog]]. She bade him deliver them to [[Aragorn]], [[Legolas]], and [[Gimli]], a task Gandalf accomplished when he met them at last in [[Fangorn Forest]].<ref>{{TT|III5}}, p. 502-3</ref> Aragorn's message was prophetic in nature, referring to the meeting of the [[Grey Company]] and his taking of the [[Paths of the Dead]]. Legolas's message would prove to be a warning, for when he was at [[Pelargir]] he heard the cry of the gulls, which awakened the [[Sea-longing]] dormant in the hearts of Elves.<ref>{{RK|Debate}}, p. 873</ref> Gimli's message was one of encouragement, for he bore three locks of Galadriel's hair.<ref>{{FR|Farewell}}, p. 376</ref>

'''Aragorn'''
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
Where now are the Dúnedain, Elessar, Elessar? 
Why do thy kinsfolk wander afar? 
Near is the hour when the Lost should come forth, 
And the Grey Company ride from the North. 
But dark is the path appointed for thee: 
The Dead watch the road that leads to the Sea. 
</poem>
'''Legolas'''
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
Legolas Greenleaf long under tree 
In joy thou hast lived. Beware of the Sea! 
If thou hearest the cry of the gull on the shore, 
Thy heart shall then rest in the forest no more.
</poem>
'''Gimli'''
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
Lock-bearer, wherever thou goest my thought goes with thee. 
But have a care to lay thine axe to the right tree!" 
</poem>
